content.content: Thanks for reading the monthly update of the DUX (Development & UX) Core Unit! These updates serve as a vehicle for transparency with regards to our work and focus. We aim to stick to the format suggested by @Artem_Gordon of GovComms. In addition to these lower-timeframe updates we do quarterly roadmap updates on the Forum. Lastly, we’re always available for inquiries on the MakerDAO Discord or on our DUX Discord server.     tl;dr February 2022 was an unusual but productive and important month for our team. Instead of the usual design & development sprints on the Governance Portal with a two-week release cadence, we have spent the whole month working on a thorough code refactor and technical research, followed by an intense team offsite scheduled around the ETHDenver conference. The time invested in February has laid the groundwork for a bunch of new features and cross-CU initiatives that our team will be executing on over the coming months.   Product updates We have been focussing on three workstreams last month; a thorough code refactor of the Governance Portal, technical research into gasless voting mechanisms, and a redesigned landing page.  Governance Portal code refactor At the end of last year we decided to take on the biggest chunk of technical debt related to the Governance Portal; its dependencies on dai.js—a library built by Maker developers earlier (pre-DAO) which enables basic web3 functionalities (eg. connecting to wallets, smart contract calls) and interactions with the Maker system (eg. interacting with Vaults). These days the web3 ecosystem is sprawling and some open-source libraries ended up becoming a more efficient and developer-friendly alternative to dai.js. In addition, maintaining the library adds huge overhead to our team when we’d rather focus on the Governance Portal codebase. The code refactor will make the Governance Portal more reliable (ie. stable and secure) but also easier to maintain and work with. Our team has worked hard on researching technical solutions and rigorously refactoring the codebase. With rigorous I’m talking 280 commits and 382 files changed so far.  We’re nearly there and the upcoming Governance Portal release will feature the refactored codebase, in addition to new features and improvements.  Gasless voting research The second workstream we have been focussing on is researching mechanisms for gasless poll voting. Decreasing the friction of participating in Maker governance is our single biggest priority at this point since we believe it’s an important lever in increasing governance participation. We have looked into various options, ranging from an integration with Snapshot to more bespoke (ie. custom-built) solutions. We have converged onto a few potential implementations which we will pitch to select CUs for feedback in the upcoming two weeks. Stay tuned for more info!  Landing page redesign While our engineers were working on the above, our designer Tiago has been working on a redesign for the Governance Portal’s landing page. We kicked off the initiative earlier this year through an ideation session in which we brainstormed which functionalities and what data should be displayed there. The landing page redesign also inspired us to rethink our data architecture—the result is a snappier Governance Portal which is more comfortable fetching large amounts of data at once. Keep your eye out for the redesign!   Team updates  Team offsite & ETHDenver conference Our entire team of six has met in Denver, CO for a two-week team offsite and conference visit. It’s been an intense but fruitful time; we spent quality time together as a team and had the opportunity to advance on some more difficult topics through an on-site workshop and low-key discussions. In addition we were able to connect with quite a few MakerDAO folks outside of our own team and discuss various topics that transcend a single CU’s mandate. We felt a strong and confident Maker presence throughout the conference, manifested not only by the sheer number of MakerDAO affiliated individuals (CU members, delegates, etc) attending but also through talks and panels, and ofcourse the incredible DAIvinity party hosted by MakerDAO. It definitely feels like the brand perception of Maker has increased compared to a year ago. Big ups to @Growth-Core-Unit for their work which brought us here. Lastly we had some fruitful encounters and conversations with individuals from other teams (eg. Yearn, Aave, Gitcoin) about protocol DAO governance challenges amongst other topics. I’m convinced that the connections and conversations that were formed during this offsite have planted seeds which will lead to initiatives later this year.  Facilitator role switch As seen on the forum in January [1] [2], @bainpm formally handed over the CU facilitator role to @0xdeniz in order to fully focus on coding, research and architecture design. The governance proposal passed which formalised the graceful transition.   Do you have any feedback or feature requests for the Governance Portal, or ideas for improving Maker’s governance UX in general? Please reach out in the comments below or join our Discord server.

SAS Monthly Update: December 2022 Hey everyone, we wish you a healthy and successful new year. Welcome to our first monthly update—we’re moving away from Sprint reviews to this new, crisp and clear format.  What happened in December?  CU Governance & Administration  Rejection of the SAS Budget Extension MIP at the end of November: Mainly due to doubt on the relevance of the Auctions Mandate and the encouragement of delegates to turn SAS into an Ecosystem Actor asap. SAS got involved in Endgame (more details in the respective section) SAS secured funding until end of March 2023   Endgame Mandate  Strategic  After several discussions with Endgame stakeholders, SAS will become a trusted custom software development service provider for SubDAOs with a Full-Stack offering: Smart contract and decentralized frontend development services accompanied by infrastructure work SAS joined the Governance-Security Group to understand where we can help best during the Pre Game Phase. Based on these discussions, SAS is currently preparing a proposal to develop a Smart Contract Toolkit for SubDAOs.   Technical  SAS kicked off Smart Contract Development in December to make sure our processes meet the quality and security standards of Maker SAS researched and established end-to-end testing capabilities that include both solidity- and Typescript-based testing. This is important for our Full-Stack approach. Analysis of several exchange callee contracts written by PE to get familiar with general structure and desired code style (issue). Development of a new exchange-callee contract that connects Maker to 1inch. The contract and its test were published and currently awaiting a review (PR). The development of the contract heavily benefited from the Full-Stack approach: The communication with the 1inch aggregation router contract required off-chain data as an input. This is hard to impossible using only Solidity-based tests.   Sunsetting Auctions  SAS decided to wind down auction-related work to the absolute minimum. We will keep ensuring that the services are working and up-to-date (e.g. for new collaterals). Now supporting GNO collateral in the Unified Auctions UI and keeper. Started packaging the Unified Auctions UI into a Desktop application to reduce the barrier to run the application locally is reduced to almost 0 (Download + Double-Click).   Outlook January  Moving forward on the described development streams (Callee Contract and Desktop App) Conceptualizing and Discussing the Smart Contract Toolkit for SubDAOs proposal Understanding and discussing Endgame Scopes to identify other work items Prepare a new MIP to secure operations beyond March 2023.

In addition to the product-related work we’ve delivered a full-day workshop focussed on DAO governance challenges, as part of the devconnect event in Amsterdam . Product updates We deployed two updates to the Governance Portal last month, and we’ve made progress on R&D projects.  Governance Portal updates On April 5th we released an update which featured ‘Share your Vote’—It enables voters to directly share their poll votes and comments to Twitter and the Governance Forum. This shrinks the gap between the Governance Portal and the Forum, makes the lives of recognized delegates a bit easier and also aims to make voting a bit more interactive. The release also included other minor improvements to commenting, various smaller optimisations, and UI improvements. On April 28th we launched another major update to the Governance Portal which features a redesign—mainly focussed on providing a more relevant and useful landing page, which serves both as the first touchpoint for users that are new to MakerDAO governance, and serves as a dashboard for existing users. The release also included various smaller improvements.  Research & Development As explained in last month’s CU update; DUX team has slowly shifted focus from isolated GovPortal work towards more research and cross-CU collaboration.  In April we’ve made progress on an implementation for gasless poll voting and presented remaining design decisions to GovAlpha. We’re currently iterating and are moving towards a final design, upon which we can start development.  We are continuing to look into ways to speed up the Governance Portal and improve stability by optimising data fetching. We are currently performing a root cause analysis related to some issues in the GovPortal stack which result in intermittent errors and flakey tests. For the longer-term we’re considering a dedicated application/service that serves as a data aggregator, which would relieve this duty from the GovPortal application.   Team updates  Contributions to Devconnect event    Last month DUX team made a significant contribution to Devconnect—a week-long conference in Amsterdam, organised by the Ethereum Foundation. We had our sights set on a sub-event called Global Governance Gathering, organised by the folks at The DAOist. The event was focussed on improving the state of DAO governance and attracted DAO thinkers and doers from all over the web3 space. We recognized the event as an opportunity to connect with fellow governance thinkers and bring some more exposure to our work at MakerDAO. @tiago and @0xdeniz designed and facilitated a full-day design sprint workshop and put in a $6.5k sponsorship (thanks to @Growth-Core-Unit ) The workshop was conducted with 11 carefully selected participants (leaders from organisations like yearn, Element and Radicle) and was hugely successful. More importantly; we forged a relationship with this group of people that will likely be valuable over time. We’ve established a Telegram chat group and will hopefully be in touch over the months/years to come. More details about the workshop were shared on the Governance & Risk Meeting #187 [video segment available here, transcript available here]. On day 2 of the DAOist GGG22 event @0xdeniz went on-stage and gave a talk about the workshop purpose and output [video recording available here] and embedded below       Besides the above contribution, three out of six DUX CU members were in Amsterdam for the Devconnect conference and connected with other MakerDAO community members, but also made connections with other web3 folks. The conference week turned out great, with some valuable new connections forged and some decent exposure to our work generated    Do you have any feedback or feature requests for the Governance Portal, or ideas for improving Maker’s governance UX in general? May Priorities  Redesigning GovComms (Continued)   ”The greatest superpower is the ability to change yourself” - Naval Ravikant  A note from the Facilitator, @Davidutro Back in April 2021, I started our team with a motivation to “improve MakerDAO’s performance … by removing information and communication barriers.” To do so, we designed a set of programs that aimed to improve the experience of the busy DAO participant by focusing on MakerDAO’s informational accessibility, stakeholder coordination, and communication practices. And yet, participants still struggle with the same barriers we set out to remove. That visible struggle indicates that although our goal is essential, we are not producing enough impact. There are several reasons why I believe we have been underperforming. Here are my top 3. Firstly, we are trying to do too much with our small team–everyone’s focus is too split, resulting in slower progress and a lack of quality. Secondly, we haven’t been approaching the information complexity problem correctly. Lastly, we are trying to simultaneously serve too many audiences(MKR holders, Core Units, Delegates, and others), resulting in suboptimal impact. A redesign of GovComms is needed. This month I worked with the team to come to some answers around; What 20% of the programs have 80% of the impact? What isn’t working and probably won’t? What programs will become obsolete? What value does each of our programs provide? What are our strengths, weaknesses, and points of leverage? Who should our primary target audience be?  1600×1108 360 KB  These essential questions are the foundation for understanding how we need to change to produce meaningful impact. My thoughts below are not final; they are being shared as a work-in-progress: Low Impact Programs   Public Relations Support; The simplest of the bunch–we will be cutting this program. Noone in the current team is a PR expert, and we could not get approval for such a hire. We believe it’s best to let Growth and their incubating Brand team take the lead here.  Issue Discussion Call Series; We do not believe this is the best format for helping the community engage with issues. We have paused this program and are considering cutting or improving it. Improvement ideas include calls-by-request, shorter formats, narrower topics, unrecorded sessions, and better-prepared issue research. TBD!  Call Summaries; 75% of our contributor budget is spent on call summaries, so we are keen to tune this program. We need to reassess calls and what level of coverage is appropriate for each.  Communication Platform Stewardship; GovAlpha and our team currently do this. Unfortunately, our team has been overwhelmed, leaving this program at the bottom of our priorities. We continue to provide basic service, but I believe we can do more if we design ourselves some extra bandwidth.  Medium Impact Programs   Stakeholder Content; Information complexity is the primary challenge this program addresses, and it’s barely made a dent. To improve effectiveness, we are trimming existing publications and upgrading our contributor workforce to include a designer(hiring!) and an additional writer. We are also considering a proposal that would position us as the content manager for blog.makerdao.com, though the incubating Brand team might be better for it. TBD!  Communications Audit; We believe SES’s upcoming Ecosystem Dashboard automates a good portion of this audit. We will wait and see whether this program makes sense in the near future.  Stakeholder Database; We believe SES’s upcoming Ecosystem Dashboard is well-positioned to integrate the stakeholder database for more streamlined management. Our team is continuing to pursue the GDPR compliance objective and is considering whether a hand-off in the near future is the wisest move.  Governance & Risk Call Support; Calls themselves are evolving at Maker, so this program is too narrowly defined. We believe a more general “Call Support” program makes sense. This way, we can be flexible and offer the same set of possible services for any call. Call Summaries would be placed within this broader call support program.  High Impact Programs   Initiative Tracking; To foster alignment, we believe creating shared visibility into initiatives will benefit both Delegates and Core Units. It will help Core Units like ours, Growth, and Brand(TBD) to maintain consistency. It will also enable better internal coordination by providing details about initiative leadership, coordination, and progress.  Stakeholder Alignment Framework; We’ve been taking part in this framework as a support team, offering call support in various ways, including acting as call facilitators/initiative coordinators. In our experience, we realized that the most effective initiative coordinators are individuals with subject matter expertise. Therefore it doesn’t make sense for us to facilitate these calls. We believe our role in this framework is to support it with initiative tracking itself, general call support, and focusing more narrowly on reporting initiatives’ status and progress.  Emergency Communications Support; This is a crucial initiative that we believe needs better-dedicated support, but we are not sure what that looks like. Support involves documentation of the emergency response process(98% done), documentation upkeep, education efforts within the DAO, and acting as a communications manager during an emergency or incident. Depending on how drastically we pivot, it might make the most sense for GovAlpha to manage the documentation and education efforts in partnership with the Immunifi Security CU. For those who are not yet familiar with the Governance Communications Core Unit, please head out to our transparency dashboard.   April Priorities  Reframing GovComms After a challenging April governance cycle, one of our two budget proposals was approved. We reached out to several stakeholders and delegates to help explain our resource needs and the strategic case for a public relations lead. We realized that many of our key stakeholders have different views and expectations of Govcomms. This lack of clarity around our mandate and its value is something we are focused on fixing. Govcomms faces a few challenges here:  The DAO (ourselves included) is starved for a powerful brand, messaging, and marketing team. We are a communications team, but we do not lead messaging, brand, or marketing. As a field of focus, Organizational Communications is not commonly set up as a stand-alone department, making it hard to understand at a glance. We are closer to an operations team than a marketing team. Organizational comms is an area that involves multiple teams at different levels and so it is challenging to convince people that a dedicated team makes sense (it does.) We are a supporting services team that does not directly drive any revenue. Our programs provide value in hard-to-measure ways that are challenging to craft into a $ saved figure. Although we’ve worked hard to optimise the UX on the app layer, migrating still requires multiple on-chain transactions—click here to learn why this is still necessary. TL;DR Last month we released the fourth iteration of the dashboard, featuring:  Dashboard user accounts; Developer experience improvements; Continued support for Core Unit onboarding and reporting  This month, we release Expense Report Auditing as a major new feature to improve reporting accuracy:   Core Unit Auditors are now explicitly listed for each core unit. This also indicates which Core Units are not working with an auditor.   Expense report status tracking makes it easy to see which expense reports are Final, and which reports are still Drafts or under Review by their auditor.   Final reports can no longer be altered by the Core Unit Administrator unless they are explicitly reopened. Auditors can Escalate problematic reports to the community.    Expense report audit trails are now clearly documented in the report’s commenting section. This includes the complete history of when a report was updated, when its status changed, and what comments were left by the Auditor and Core Unit Administrator.   We will finish core unit on-boarding with the final core unit, Data Insights (DIN), by the end of the month. Try it out  Visit our dashboard at https://expenses.makerdao.network/  The GraphQL API can be accessed using the API Explorer  Download the latest Budget Reporting Tool here   NOTICE - the official repository for the Budget Reporting Tool releases was moved to Releases · makerdao-ses/ecosystem-reporting-tool-v1 · GitHub. Core Unit Auditors See how Core Units are evaluated.  2410×1266 201 KB  The Maker Governance community, and other stakeholders, can now easily see who a Core Unit’s auditor are with Auditor Roles. Auditors can update the status of the budget report on the dashboard, providing data consumers with a quick update on the progress of the budget statement in the reporting process. View the Auditor Role  On the Core Unit About Page of a specific Core Unit, giving quick access to this information at a glance. Within the Comments tab of the Expense Reports Page of specific Core Units, allowing users to understand who different roles within the conversation and changes taking place within an Expense Report.    2. Expense Report Status Tracking Easily see how final an expense report is  2410×1260 212 KB    No more need to guess what the status of an Expense Report is. The status is now clearly visible on the Expense Reports page of each Core Unit.   Four status codes are available: Draft, Review, Final, and Escalated. The data of final and escalated reports can no longer be changed unless they are explicitly reopened.   The only people that can influence these status changes are Core Unit Administrators and Core Unit Auditor roles.   Note that currently, most Expense Reports are still marked as Draft. We will work with the Core Unit Administrators to review past reports and get them up-to-date by the end of next month.   How does it work? To better explain how and when status transitions can happen, we have provided a diagram below.  2410×1260 166 KB   3. Expense Report Audit Trails Get the full Expense Report picture with a complete timeline of events in the comments tab  2410×1282 182 KB    Core Unit Auditors can now provide further context on the Budget Report in the form of comments. Making any changes that need to be made clearer for Core Unit administrators.   Further, any events changing the status of the budget statement can also be viewed in the Comments tab alongside the comments. Allowing users to view how the report has evolved since its original form.   For a more intuitive user experience, we combined all the change tracking events related to the expense report in its comments tab.   Giving the comments section, including status transitions, a timeline feel so that Core Unit Administrators and Auditors can have the full context of what changes happened over time.     What’s next? We are finishing 2022 with all the pieces in place to have accurate expense reporting for all Core Units. In the first months of 2023 we plan to build on top of this functionality, expanding it in multiple directions:   Next to Core Unit budgets, we plan to provide similar budget details for all of the Maker Protocol’s operational expenses   Existing expense structures such as Special Purpose Funds, Delegates’ compensation, and various contingency buffers.   With the Endgame Plan taking shape we expect to soon add budgets for new operational structures too. This includes Scopes, Projects, SubDAOs, and potentially Ecosystem Actors.     With detailed financial reports in place, we can start adding aggregated views to the dashboard as well. Financial summaries will allow stakeholders to view total expenses over time, with the ability to filter for specific budget categories and parameters.   The features we are offering so far will be leveraged to role out Project Based Budgeting, which will include KPIs, milestones, and deliverables next to the financial data.     Holiday Break Before all this, however, @SES-Core-Unit will take our New Year’s break. The team will be out in the coming two weeks, from December 24th until January 9th.   We wish everyone some well-deserved time off and a Happy New Year!    Feedback? We’re happy to answer your questions here, on our SES Discord server, or SES CU channel in the MakerDAO Discord.
